content.text: Brokers are the nervous system of the contractor economy. They sit between corps and contractors, matching jobs to crews and taking a cut of everything.
A broker network is a platform ‚Äî digital, physical, or both ‚Äî where contracts are posted and contractors register. Think of it as a job board for people who fight monsters for a living.

Registration is free. Your profile includes: skillset, augment loadout (as much as you‚Äôre willing to disclose), toxicity reading (mandatory), survival record (mission count, scar count, crew history), and specializations. Brokers use this data to match you with appropriate contracts and compatible crews.

Contracts are posted by corps (directly or through intermediaries), private clients, settlement councils, or occasionally other contractors. Each contract listing includes: objective, location, expected threat level, pay structure, and special requirements. What it doesn‚Äôt include: accurate threat assessments (sometimes), the real reason the job exists (often), and what happened to the last crew (usually).

The cut is typically 10-15% of the contract payout, deducted automatically. Higher-tier brokers charge more but offer better contracts, better intel, and better crew-matching. Budget brokers charge less but their intel is unreliable and they‚Äôll match you with anyone who has a pulse.

content.text: Broker NPCs are valuable contacts. A good relationship with a broker means better contracts, advance notice of high-paying jobs, and the occasional favor. A bad relationship means garbage contracts, unreliable intel, and crew-matching that puts you with people who got their last team killed.
Not everything is corporate. The spaces between corps are filled with smaller factions that contractors encounter regularly.

entries.label: Pay
entries.value: Low. Gratitude is high. They remember who helped them.

entries.value: Thousands of independent operators, not one organization

entries.value: Harvesting is ascension. More rifts is progress. The other side has answers.
